organizations.name: NASA

people.name: Suni Williams

Initial vehicle for Williams and Wilmore's transport to ISS.
organizations.name: Boeing

quote: “In my view, they’re never stuck or stranded. They always had a way to depart the space station.” - Steve Stich, NASA Commercial Crew Program Manager
summary: Elon Musk, CEO of SpaceX, made claims on social media that two astronauts were left 'stranded' on the International Space Station by the Biden administration, and indicated that SpaceX would bring them home. However, NASA had already initiated plans months earlier for SpaceX to return astronauts Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore as part of its Crew-9 mission due to concerns with Boeing's Starliner spacecraft, which experienced technical failures. The situation was portrayed as if the astronauts were stranded, but NASA clarified they were never without an option to return as they were always included in routine rotation plans. The decision to use SpaceX was partly due to safety concerns informed by past experiences with space shuttle disasters. Despite the social media controversy, NASA confirmed that both the astronauts and SpaceX were aligned on the mission timeline and Crew-9 would bring them back safely.
title: Elon Musk says SpaceX will bring home astronauts that he claims were left ‘stranded’— but NASA announced that plan months ago

author: Darrell Proctor

facts: Reported a 45% increase in solar and an 18% increase in wind power generation capacity in 2024.
organizations.name: China's National Energy Administration

facts: Advocates for climate solutions and commented on China's renewable energy efforts.
people.name: Daniel Jasper

facts: Reported that half of China's 2024 overseas power projects were renewable energy, including solar and hydro.
organizations.name: Wood Mackenzie

facts: Commented on Chinese priority in deploying greener technology overseas under the Belt & Road Initiative.
people.name: Alex Whitworth
people.position: Vice President, Head of Asia Pacific Power and Renewables Research

quote: “While China’s overall emissions are the largest of any single country, they have recognized – at least, in part – that rapidly building renewables is essential for energy and climate security,” said Daniel Jasper, senior policy advisor at Project Drawdown.
summary: In 2024, China installed a record 357 gigawatts of wind and solar power, significantly surpassing previous annual additions and meeting a 2030 renewable energy target six years early. Despite this growth, coal-fired power remains a dominant part of China's energy mix, as the country's total power generation from coal, oil, natural gas, and nuclear power reached 6.34 trillion kilowatt-hours. While China's emissions are the largest globally, their renewable energy expansion positions them to lead in global climate initiatives. Despite challenges in achieving net-zero targets, China continues to export significant amounts of renewable technology under the Belt and Road Initiative, deploying 24 gigawatts of capacity overseas in 2024 alone.
title: China built out record amount of wind and solar power in 2024
